name: Michael John Helterbrand
bio:
Michael is currently serving a 40-year sentence stemming from an FBI-manufactured plot targeting members of The Base’s Georgia cell.

According to National Justice, an undercover FBI agent persistently pushed Michael and others toward a planned act of violence, despite early reluctance and repeated delays by the group.

One of the now convicted members is Brian Mark Lemley. Lemley once confessed to having Jewish heritage, which is cited in court documents. According to CBC’s The Fifth Estate, the group had also been infiltrated by a journalist with the Winnipeg Free Press and a member of Antifa.

Just a few months into his decades-long detention, Michael began to rack up additional time for his association with prison ‘gangs.’ Floyd County Jail, where Helterbrand was originally detained at, is within White-minority county and city.

Michael’s case reflects broader concerns about government entrapment tactics and the way the prison system can force vulnerable Whites further into a criminal underworld.

name: Patrik Jordan Mathews
bio:
Patrik is a Canadian who crossed the U.S. border without papers and was swiftly branded a domestic terrorist after an FBI entrapment scheme left him and several other members of The Base with a nine-year federal prison sentence.

According to CBS News, U.S. District Judge Theodore Chuang applied a "terrorism enhancement" to Mathews' sentence, stating that recorded conversations between Mathews and Lemley captured the "virulence" and "passion" in their willingness to kill people and bring down the U.S. government.

But National Justice notes that "after a long fishing expedition, the federal government was reduced to charging them with a multitude of immigration related crimes… and a number of gun technicalities," and that the case relied heavily on surveillance and speculation rather than actual violence.

One of the now convicted members who transported Matthews was Brian Mark Lemley. Lemley once confessed to having Jewish heritage, which is cited in court documents. According to CBC’s The Fifth Estate, the group had also been infiltrated by a journalist with the Winnipeg Free Press and a member of Antifa.

name: Jacob Mark Robards
bio:
Jacob is currently serving a 10-year federal prison sentence after being swept up in an FBI drug for guns scheme targeting members of the Aryan Strikeforce.

At the time of the sting, Jacob was battling cancer, living with a disability, and experiencing homelessness.

According to National Justice, undercover FBI agents conceived, orchestrated, and controlled the entire operation — providing fake methamphetamine, posing as both buyers and sellers, and directing every step of the alleged conspiracy.

As PennLive reports, the FBI introduced the scheme at a 2016 meeting in Virginia, but later claimed that audio recordings of the meeting were "lost" due to an equipment malfunction, depriving defendants of potentially exonerating evidence.

There was no indication the conspiracy would have existed without the FBI’s involvement, raising serious concerns about government overreach.

name: Aimenn Penny
bio:
Aimenn is currently serving an 18-year federal prison sentence after being convicted of violating the Church Arson Prevention Act and weapons crimes charges. At the time of his arrest, he was only 20-years-old.

The Community Church of Chesterland, OH and its former pastor, Reverend Jess Peacock (seen below) were planning to host a drag show for children. Aimenn reportedly threw molotov cocktails at the church, causing what appears to be localized surface damage. The attack took place outside of business hours, between 12 and 2 am on March 25, 2023. The damage was described in by an FBI agent as "scorch marks" and damage to a sign.



Aimenn is scheduled for release on August 28, 2038.

In April of 2024, the church, Peacock and several other churchgoers filed a federal civil rights lawsuit against Penny. The suit also included named and unnamed members of a White Lives Matter chapter as defendants. Within the suit, the plaintiffs claim numerous damages including repair costs, lost revenue from a client that rented out a daycare center, muscle spasms and loss of breath while attending church.

Through great fortune, the plaintiffs have attracted the litigation skills of the anti-White Zionist Jew, James Pasch. Pasch currently serves as the Vice-President of Litigation at the Anti-Defamation League (or ADL). Remarkably, the ADL seems to see no conflict in criticizing white racialism in the courtroom, while it's leader laments "that intermarriage rates [among Jews] continue to go up. Assimilation continues apace."

Aimenn is currently held at Federal Corrections Institution McDowell in McDowell County, WV on the border of Northern Virginia. The dual-facility sits atop a decapitated mountain that was long ago exploited for its coal.

The area's 18,400 plus population is estimated to be around 87% White with a median income 25% lower than the national average. The average resident is around 13% older than the average American.

The presence of these troubling statistics continue to fly in the face of what was the original understanding with McDowell's residents in 2004: the feds build a prison, and you get a decent job.

5 years after the first construction, the prison began accepting job applications. Some time after it's opening in 2010, reports from local news showed that less than 14% of the facility's first hiring batch were from McDowell County.

The fact that the local news organizations tracking this story have since shut down further suggests that FCI McDowell did little to rescue a formerly prosperous county, once known as America's leading coal producer.

Aimenn is a Wotanist, which is a follower of Germanic Paganism. His daily activities include working out, watching the news, and reading before bed. On most days, Aimenn checks his email where he can be contacted directly or via our free proxy service.

You can read a Substack post written by Aimenn here.

name: Sarah Clendaniel
bio:
Sarah Clendaniel is currently serving 18-years in federal prison after she pled guilty to charges related to an FBI-involved scheme to attack the Baltimore power grid.

The prosecution claimed that Sarah and her co-defendant, Brandon Russell, would have done a whopping $75 million in damage to various power stations using only guns and mylar balloons.

Her scheduled release data is June 5, 2038.

Clendaniel’s plea agreement contains quotes indicating her mental state was compromised and that she was behaving recklessly:

"Clendaniel asked [Confidential Human Source 1] to purchase a rifle for her, stating that she wanted to ‘accomplish something worthwhile’ before her death."

The document also reiterates Clendaniel’s kidney failure; an eventually fatal condition. This tactic of targeting the sick or dying was also used in the Jacob Robards case.

Like other targets of the FBI’s anti-White stings, Clendaniel was also compromised by past drug use and a record of prior convictions.

An FBI collaborator was instrumental to the conspiracy, another common theme to FBI stings. One of several confidential informants was to deliver both the weapons and Sarah herself to the alleged attack sites. As Sarah had only recently regained her license, she said that she did not feel comfortable operating a motor vehicle.

Accused alongside Sarah was Brandon Russell, Clendaniel’s reported boyfriend. He pleaded not guilty to all charges but was eventually convicted and was sentenced in August of 2025 to 20 years in prison. Brandon is expected to appeal.

One month after Russell’s conviction, a confidential informant for the prosecution revealed he had been paid $7,000 the week of jury selection for Brandon. The same witness received $70,000 in total for similar ‘services’ rendered to the FBI but had allegedly failed to disclose the most recent payment.

Nevertheless, Judge James K. Bredar did not think this sufficient to hold a new trial. The same judge had once dismissed a potential juror who claimed to be a racist, saying, "you're excused. We don't tolerate racist views in the justice system."

During Brandon and Sarah’s legal proceedings, FBI Director Wray made a speech where he said that the FBI used a warrantless Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (or FISA) wiretap to disrupt a planned attack on a power grid that same year.

The defense suggested that Wray was referencing Brandon and Sarah’s case and thus, the FBI had violated their rights. The prosecution dismissed this as speculative.

Despite the unexpected intervention of the ACLU on Russell’s behalf, the government kept their secrets. In a private session with the prosecution, antiracist Judge Bredar agreed that both Russell’s and Clendaniel’s rights were protected, claiming that the government did not use evidence from a FISA wiretap.

name: Stephen Pattison
bio:
Stephen is currently serving a 9-year federal prison sentence after being convicted of possession of a firearm and ammunition by a convicted felon.

He is scheduled for release on August 23, 2028.

Stephen is presently located at the United States Penitentiary, Florence High in central Colorado. The prison shares a campus with the notorious ADX Florence, a facility known as the "Alcatraz of the Rockies."

Despite his somewhat moderate charges, Stephen finds himself among some of America's most notorious convicted terrorists, including several who are linked to Al-Qaeda.

According to a criminal complaint filed by the anti-White FBI agent, Adam Paradowski, the local Joint Terrorism Task Force became aware of Stephen when he counter-protested Black Lives Matter. At both of the protests in September 2020, Paradowski noted that Pattison was merely near people that were engaged in arguments or confrontations. Some of which included threats.

According to Paradowski, police happened upon Stephen during an Upstate New York traffic stop, realizing that Stephen had a warrant out for his arrest for absconding parole in Missouri. Stephen tells SE that this leaves out many crucial details, including the fact that the same government that filed this warrant never pursued a conviction. Stephen further explained that he was not absconding parole, he was living openly with his family and had been transferred to the supervision of New York State.

Additionally, Stephen said that the traffic stop occurred down the road from his home and was the culmination of several days worth of surveillance that included regular drone flyovers. All of this took place while Antifascist criminals were threatening his entire family, including his children.

If Stephen's attorney ever raised these issues, The Solidarity Exchange was unable to find any evidence of it.

During Stephen's sentencing phase, his own attorney referred to his views as "repugnant to most Americans," and called him a "neo-Nazi." The unoriginal Judge Larimer would suggest to Stephen that he use his time in prison to get an education and to read the anti-racist Black poet, Maya Angelou.

Today, Stephen remains dedicated to his race, which includes several children of his own. He prefers to spend his days at Florence socializing with his white friends or in long debates about race and history with inmates of other backgrounds. When finances allows, he calls family and friends.

Stephen always welcomes letters from his comrades.

name: Joshua Michael Steever
bio:
Joshua, founder of the Aryan Strikeforce, is serving a 20-year sentence after becoming the main target of an FBI operation that manufactured a drugs for guns conspiracy from start to finish.

PennLive reports that federal agents orchestrated all aspects of the alleged "drugs-for-guns" plot, using fake methamphetamine and staging sales for gift cards allegedly meant to buy weapons.

Steever ultimately pleaded guilty to conspiracy to distribute controlled substances despite no real meth being involved.

As National Justice notes, there was no existing conspiracy until FBI undercover employees infiltrated the group, supplied the drugs, posed as buyers, and drove the entire plan. Several defendants, including a cancer-stricken, homeless co-defendant, Jacob Mark Robards, were drawn into the operation while facing desperate circumstances.

name: Brandon Clint Russell
bio:
Brandon Russell is currently incarcerated—most recently in Maryland State Prison—after being convicted of conspiracy to damage an energy facility in an FBI-involved scheme.

In August of 2025, Brandon was sentenced to the allowed maximum of 20 years in prison. He reportedly plans to appeal.

The prosecution claimed that Brandon and his co-defendant, reported girlfriend Sarah Clendaniel, would have done a whopping $75 million in damage to various power stations using only guns and mylar balloons.

Sarah, who pleaded guilty and received an 18-year sentence for her alleged role in the plot, was dying of kidney failure at the time of the sting.

Brandon would attempt to identify the government's confidential informants but his legal motions were defeated and he was convicted in February of 2025.

One of the anonymous witnesses would reveal that he had been paid $70,000 by the FBI during his four years as a per diem professional informant. One month after Russell was convicted, the government revealed the same witness had been paid an additional $7,000 that he failed to disclose. This payment was sent the week of jury selection.

Nevertheless, Judge James K. Bredar did not think this sufficient to hold a new trial. The same judge had once dismissed a potential juror who claimed to be a racist, saying, "you're excused. We don't tolerate racist views in the justice system."

During Brandon and Sarah’s legal proceedings, FBI Director Wray made a public speech where he said that the FBI used a warrantless Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (or FISA) wiretap to disrupt a planned attack on the power grid that same year.

The defense suggested that Wray was referencing Brandon and Sarah’s case and thus, violated their rights. The prosecution dismissed this as speculative, refusing to confirm or deny the implication.

Despite the unexpected intervention of the ACLU on Russell’s behalf, the government kept their secrets. In a private session with the prosecution, antiracist Judge Bredar agreed that Russell’s rights were protected and that the government did not use evidence from a FISA wiretap.

Brandon is a veteran of the Florida National Guard and has an undergraduate degree in Nuclear Physics. He is a dual citizen of both the United States and the Bahamas. During his current stay in a Maryland state prison, Russell began his own newsletter titled simply, White Prison Newsletter.
